p: Diabetes mellitus is one of the most common metabolic disorders, characterized by insulin malfunction and hyperglycemia due to inadequate insulin secretion, or both of them [ 132]. In 2019, 463 million adults worldwide were estimated to have diabetes mellitus, and these figures are expected to rise to 700 million by 2045 [ 133]. The effects of Rhus coriaria on type II diabetes was studied by examining serum glycemic status, apolipoprotein (apo) B, apoA-I and total antioxidant capacity (TAC) in type II diabetic patients. Type II patients consuming a powder of Rhus coriaria (3.0 g, daily for 3 months) showed a significant decrease in the levels of serum glucose, HbA1c, ApoB, and ApoA-I and an increase in the total antioxidant capacity [ 78]. Furthermore, administration of Rhus coriaria hydroalcoholic seed extract significantly decreased the level of glucose and cholesterol in nicotinamide-streptozotocin-induced type II diabetic male mice [ 73]. Furthermore, LDL-cholesterol level decreased while the level of leptin significantly increased in those mice when treated with a dose of 300 mg/kg of the hydroalcoholic extract [ 73].
